title: Moments in Hangzhou
text:
Things must do in Hangzhou

1. Wait for sunset at the lakeside ğŸŒ…



A video captured by Weisi at Yongjinmen on 20 Jan 2025, located on the southern shore of West Lake.


2. Look at the so-called â€˜most beautiful cornerâ€™ of Gushan.



A video captured by Weisi at Gushan on 20 Jan 2025, located on the northern shore of West Lake.

title: About Hangzhou | éŸµå‘³æ­å· I
text:
Born and raised in Hangzhou, I spent eighteen years there before moving to Sydney, Australia. During my years in Hangzhou, I didnâ€™t fully appreciate its beauty, often feeling more drawn to larger cities like Shanghai and Beijing. However, after relocating to Sydney, everything changed. I began to deeply miss Hangzhouâ€”the weeping willows by the lake in spring, the blooming lotus flowers in summer, the vibrant red maple leaves on Beishan Street in autumn and the pervasive scent of osmanthus in the air, the wintersweets and the misty mornings of drizzly winter days. Even my momâ€™s homemade Hangzhou cuisine, though not entirely authentic, became a cherished memory.
Due to COVID restrictions and work and study commitments, I hadnâ€™t been home in six years. When I finally returned, I was struck by a profound sense of alienation. Familiar restaurants and shops near my home had disappeared. The large square where people once gathered to dance, socialize, and sing had been replaced by two sprawling shopping malls. The city itself had transformedâ€”its subway system had expanded from just two lines six years ago to eight lines, now covering almost every corner. Towering high-rises filled the cityscape, one after another, creating a stark contrast to the Hangzhou I once knew.
Yet, amidst all these changes, West Lake remained the same. Walking along its shores, I was once again captivated by its timeless beauty and serenity. Some say Hangzhou is defined by just one lake, but to me, its charm lies in so much moreâ€”the natural landscapes, cultural and historical heritage, poetry, and art. Itâ€™s no wonder Bai Juyi, the renowned Tang dynasty poet, once wrote: â€œWhen I recall the south of the Yangtze River, Hangzhou comes foremost to my mindâ€ (å¿†æ±Ÿå—ï¼Œæœ€å¿†æ˜¯æ­å·).
So here it isâ€”Hangzhou, my beloved city.



West lake, Hangzhou. Photo sourced online.

About Hangzhou
Hangzhou (æ­å·) is the capital city of the Zhejiang providence. Nestled in the heart of eastern China, Hangzhou is a city where timeless charm meets vibrant modernity. Renowned for its breathtaking West Lake (è¥¿æ¹–), a symbol of natural beauty and serenity, Hangzhou has inspired poets and painters for centuries. Beyond its historic allure, the city thrives as a hub of innovation, home to global tech giant Alibaba and a burgeoning digital economy. With its harmonious blend of ancient temples, bustling markets, cutting-edge architecture, and verdant tea plantations, Hangzhou offers a captivating journey through history and progress.


Beishan St (åŒ—å±±è¡—)  <ä¸€æ¡åŒ—å±±è¡—ï¼ŒåŠæ­¥æ°‘å›½å²>
Beishan Street (åŒ—å±±è¡—) is a picturesque historic avenue that runs along the northern shore of the iconic West Lake. Known for its blend of natural beauty and cultural heritage, the street is lined with ancient trees, traditional Chinese architecture, and several historical sites, including former residences of notable figures and old temples. The area exudes a tranquil charm, making it a favorite spot for leisurely strolls, photography, and cultural exploration. Visitors often admire its cobblestone paths, scenic lake views, and the way it seamlessly combines modernity with history. Beishan Street is not just a thoroughfare but a journey into Hangzhouâ€™s rich past, offering a serene retreat from the cityâ€™s bustling pace.

Beishan St (åŒ—å±±è¡—)



åŒ—å±±è¡— (Beishan St) in winter. It is most beautiful in autumn where the street is lined with vibrant red maple leaves ğŸ. Photo captured by Weisi on the 7 Jan 2025.


ä¿å”å¡” (Boshu Pagoda)

 

åŒ—å±±è¡— (Beishan St), ä¿å”å¡” (Boshu Pagoda) in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on 7 Jan 2025. The ä¿å”å¡” (Boshu Pagoda) is a historic and iconic landmark situated on å®çŸ³å±± (Precious Stone Hill) near the northern shores of West Lake. Its origins trace back to äº”ä»£åå›½ (Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms) period, build in 968. Historically, the pagoda served both a religious purpose - as a Buddhist structure, it symbolized blessings and peace.  Over the centuries, the Baoshu Pagoda has undergone multiple reconstructions due to damage from natural wear and conflicts. The most recent restoration was completed in the 20th century, ensuring its preservation for future generations. The pagoda is renowned for its slender and elegant design, standing at 45.3 meters tall. Its architectural style is distinct, with a gracefully tapering structure that appears almost like a delicate needle pointing toward the sky. Hence, there is an old saying: â€œæ¹–ä¸Šä¸¤æµ®å± ï¼Œå®çŸ³å¦‚ç¾äººï¼Œé›·å³°å¦‚è€è¡²â€ (â€œThe two pagodas on the lake, Baoshu like a beautiful woman, Leifeng like an old monkâ€). Today, the Baoshu Pagoda remains a beloved feature of Hangzhouâ€™s landscape, admired for its historical importance and the breathtaking views it offers of West Lake and the surrounding area. Its presence is a testament to the cityâ€™s long-standing cultural and architectural achievements. 


Lingering Snow on Broken Bridge (æ–­æ¡¥æ®‹é›ª)

  

 The Broken Bridge (æ–­æ¡¥) in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on the 7 Jan 2025. The Broken Bridge is located at the eastern end of Bai Causeway on the West Lake. One end connects to Beishan Road on the north shore of West Lake, while the other end leads to the Mid-Lake Pavilion in the Autumn Moon over the Calm Lake (å¹³æ¹–ç§‹æœˆ) and the Solitary Hill (å­¤å±±). The current bridge was rebuilt in 1921. The origin of the name â€œBroken Bridgeâ€ There are many legends about the origin of the name â€œBroken Bridge.â€ One famous legend describes that after a winter snow, when viewed from Baoshi Hill to the south, West Lake is draped in silver, with Bai Causeway stretching across snow-covered willows and frosted peach trees. The stone arches of the Broken Bridge are exposed, with no cover or barriers, allowing the ice and snow to melt under the sunlight, while the ends of the bridge remain covered in bright white snow. The faintly visible stone bridge arches seem to appear and disappear, contrasting with the gray-brown bridge deck, creating an illusion of the bridge being broken. Thus, it is named the Broken Bridge. It is selected as one of the Ten Scenes of West Lake, named â€œLingering Snow on Broken Bridge (æ–­æ¡¥æ®‹é›ª)â€.  Love Bridge The Broken Bridge in Hangzhou holds a special place in Chinese folklore as one of the â€œThree Love Bridgesâ€ and is famously associated with the legend â€œThe Legend of the White Snakeâ€ (ç™½è›‡ä¼ ). According to the tale, it was on the Broken Bridge that Bai Niangzi (ç™½å¨˜å­), a white snake spirit, and Xu Xian (è®¸ä»™), a mortal man, first crossed paths. This chance meeting blossomed into a legendary romance that remains one of Chinaâ€™s most cherished love stories.



Solitary Hill (å­¤å±±)  <ç»¿æ¨é˜´é‡Œç™½æ²™å ¤>

Bai Causeway (ç™½å ¤)



 Photo captured by Weisi on January 7, 2025. Bai Causeway (ç™½å ¤) in winterâ€”a picturesque path lined with willow trees swaying gracefully in the wind. This serene scene evokes the timeless beauty of spring, when the causeway comes alive with vibrant willow trees, blooming flowers, and elegant bridges. Inspired by such scenery, the renowned Tang Dynasty poet Bai Juyi (ç™½å±…æ˜“) penned the famous poem ã€Šé’±å¡˜æ¹–æ˜¥è¡Œã€‹ (Spring Walk by Qiantang Lake):
å­¤å±±å¯ºåŒ—è´¾äº­è¥¿ï¼Œæ°´é¢åˆå¹³äº‘è„šä½ã€‚ å‡ å¤„æ—©èºäº‰æš–æ ‘ï¼Œè°å®¶æ–°ç‡•å•„æ˜¥æ³¥ã€‚ ä¹±èŠ±æ¸æ¬²è¿·äººçœ¼ï¼Œæµ…è‰æ‰èƒ½æ²¡é©¬è¹„ã€‚ æœ€çˆ±æ¹–ä¸œè¡Œä¸è¶³ï¼Œç»¿æ¨é˜´é‡Œç™½æ²™å ¤ã€‚ (To the north of Gushan Temple and west of Jia Pavilion,  The water surface just leveled, with clouds hanging low. Early orioles vie for warm trees, while new swallows peck at spring mud. Wildflowers almost dazzle the eyes, and tender grass barely covers horse hooves. I love strolling along the east side of the lake most, Where green willows cast their shade over the white sandy causeway.) 


Xiling Bridge (è¥¿æ³ æ¡¥) & Su Xiaoxiao (è‹å°å°)

  

 Xiling Bridge (è¥¿æ³ æ¡¥): Leading to Beishan, with Bai Causeway is close by, and Su Causeway faintly visible. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025.  Love Bridge The ancient legend of Su Xiaoxiao (è‹å°å°) unfolds here. Su Xiaoxiao was a Song Dynasty courtesan, born in Hangzhou. Her home was near Xicun. Su Xiaoxiao was intelligent, beautiful, talented, and dignified. Once, while traveling by carriage to enjoy the scenery at Bai Causeway, she encountered a young man named Ruan Yu (son of the prime minister of the Southern Qi Dynasty), who was slowly approaching on a green horse from the Broken Bridge. They fell in love at first sight. After Su Xiaoxiaoâ€™s death, she was buried beside Xiling Bridge at Xiling Bank. Later generations built a Mucai Pavilion (æ…•æ‰äº­) on her tomb, and visitors passing by the bridge would pay their respects at her grave.



Xiling Seal Art Society (è¥¿æ³ å°ç¤¾)



 Xiling Seal Art Society (è¥¿æ³ å°ç¤¾) in summer, covered in green. Photo sourced online. 

 

 Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. The Xiling Seal Art Society (è¥¿æ³ å°ç¤¾), established in 1904 in Hangzhou, is a prestigious organization dedicated to preserving and promoting traditional Chinese arts, particularly seal carving, calligraphy, and painting. Its idyllic location near West Lake and its legacy of artistic and cultural excellence make it a significant landmark in Chinese art history. In recent years, the Xiling Seal Art Society has gained additional attention through its mention in the popular Chinese tomb-raiding adventure novel series, ç›—å¢“ç¬”è®° (The Lost Tomb), by å—æ´¾ä¸‰å” (Nanpai Sanshu). This integration into the narrative adds an air of mystery and historical intrigue to the societyâ€™s rich heritage. The immense popularity of the novel series has drawn millions of young visitors from across China, eager to experience the cultural and artistic atmosphere of this iconic site firsthand. 


Qiu Jin (ç§‹ç‘¾): A Heroine Among Heroes



 Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025.  Qiu Jin (ç§‹ç‘¾) (1875â€“1907), a trailblazing revolutionary and feminist, is celebrated as a national heroine in Chinese history. Born in Fujian and raised in Zhejiang, Qiu Jin grew up during a time of great social and political turmoil in late Qing China. Known as the â€œWoman Knight of Mirror Lakeâ€ (é‰´æ¹–å¥³ä¾ ), she became a symbol of courage, independence, and the fight for equality.  In her lifetime, she once said, â€œIf I die, I would like to be buried in Xiling (å¦‚æœä¸å¹¸ç‰ºç‰²ï¼Œæ„¿åŸ‹éª¨è¥¿æ³ )â€. After a number of relocation, Qiu Jinâ€™s tomb was finally from the Jilong Hill to the side of the Xiling Bridge in September 1981. On the front of her tombâ€™s pedestal is an inscription by Dr.Â Sun Yat-sen (å­™ä¸­å±±) that honors her legacy: â€œHeroine Among Heroes (å·¾å¸¼è‹±é›„).â€ 


Wenlan Pavilion (æ–‡æ¾œé˜): A Treasure of Chinese Culture

    

 Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025.  Wenlan Pavilion (æ–‡æ¾œé˜) is one of the esteemed â€œSeven Pavilions of the Complete Library in Four Sectionsâ€ (ä¸ƒé˜è—ä¹¦æ¥¼). Constructed in 1782 during the Qing Dynasty under the decree of Emperor Qianlong, it was designed to house a copy of the monumental literary collection, Siku Quanshu (å››åº“å…¨ä¹¦, Imperial Collection of Four Divisions). This compilation, regarded as the largest collection of Chinese texts in history, encompasses works across the four divisions: classics, history, philosophy, and literature. While other Qing Dynasty libraries were either safeguarded in imperial locations or tragically lost to the flames of war, Wenlan Pavilion and its Imperial Collection of Four Divisions endured. Despite facing the ravages of conflict and the changes of time, it was ultimately restored, thanks to the persistent efforts of generations of literati and scholars who recognized, transcribed, and preserved the scattered volumes. This remarkable survival stands as a cultural miracle in Chinese history. Today, Wenlan Pavilion, situated by the picturesque West Lake, continues to embody profound cultural significance. It serves as a living testament to the enduring legacy of Chinese culture and scholarship, spreading its rich humanistic heritage to the world. 



Nanshan Rd (å—å±±è·¯)

Orioles Singing in the Willows (æŸ³æµªé—»èº)




The entry to the Orioles Singing in the Willows (æŸ³æµªé—»èº) park in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. It is most beautiful in spring, where the gentle rustling of willow branches in the breeze and the melodious calls of orioles create a symphony of nature that enchants visitors.


 


Orioles Singing in the Willows (æŸ³æµªé—»èº) park in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025.




æ¹–æ»¨ (Lakeside)

  


Hand-rowed boat parked at the West Lake. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. One of the most cherished activities at West Lake is enjoying a leisurely ride on a hand-rowed boat, gently drifting across its serene waters.


Juxian Pavilion (é›†è´¤äº­)

 


Juxian Pavilion (é›†è´¤äº­) in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. In the fourth year of the Yongzheng reign of the Qing Dynasty (1726), Li Wei, the Governor of Zhejiang, rebuilt the Archery Pavilion, renaming it Juxian Pavilion (Pavilion of Gathering Virtues). He used this location to inspect the military training of the Eight Banners troops. Over time, Tingzi Bay gradually became a regular venue for the Eight Banners soldiers to practice horseback archery and martial arts. Today, Juxian Pavilion is a popular destination where people gather to enjoy the scenic views and capture stunning photos, especially at sunset. It is at its most beautiful in summer, surrounded by the vibrant blooms of nearby lotus flowers.



First Park (ä¸€å…¬å›­)



ä¸€å…¬å›­(Yi Gongyuan), or â€œFirst Parkâ€, is a well-known and historic public situated near the bustling lakeside area of West Lake. Its prime location makes it a favorite destination for morning exercise, singing and dancing, social gatherings, and soaking in the picturesque views of West Lake.


Yongjin Pool (æ¶Œé‡‘æ± )

 


Yongjin Pool (æ¶Œé‡‘æ± ) is a well-known scenic spot, famous for its golden ox and the legend associated with it. According to the tale, in the Han Dynasty, a golden ox lay hidden at the bottom of West Lake. Whenever the lake dried up, causing crops to wither and people to suffer from water shortages, the golden ox would emerge, spouting water to refill the lake, providing irrigation for nearby farmlands and meeting the daily water needs of the local people. In an attempt to please the emperor, local officials once forced the villagers to drain the lake to capture the golden ox as a tribute. When the lake was emptied and the golden ox appeared, the officials rushed into the lake to seize it. However, the golden ox raised its head and roared in anger, spewing water that quickly flooded the area, drowning all the officials. From that time on, the waters of West Lake never dried up again, and the golden ox was never seen.  The â€œGolden Ox Emerging from Waterâ€ sculpture in Yongjin Pool was erected in 2002. A waterside pier has also been built on the eastern shore of Yongjin Pool to provide visitors with a spot for taking photos and enjoying the scenery. The first photo is captured by Weisi on 6 Jan 2025. The second photo is sourced from the internet.




Hefang Street (æ²³åŠè¡—)
Hefang Ancient Street (æ²³åŠè¡—) is one of Hangzhouâ€™s oldest and most iconic streets, tracing its origins back to the Southern Song Dynasty and reaching its peak prosperity in the Qing Dynasty. It serves as a vibrant window into the cityâ€™s rich cultural heritage, where the echoes of history come alive amidst a bustling modern scene. This historic pedestrian street is adorned with beautifully preserved Qing Dynasty-style architecture and is a treasure trove of traditional crafts, local delicacies, and cultural charm. Among its highlights is Huqingyutang(èƒ¡åº†ä½™å ‚), a renowned traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) pharmacy and museum established in 1874. Additionally, artisans craft intricate calligraphy brushes, delicate silk umbrellas, and other traditional goods, while food stalls offer classic Hangzhou treats like beggarâ€™s chicken (å«èŠ±é¸¡) and sweet osmanthus cake (æ¡‚èŠ±ç³•). Hefang Ancient Street is a unique journey through time, blending the allure of the past with the vitality of the present.

 


Hefang Street (æ²³åŠè¡—): A historic street blending cultural heritage with modern vibrancy. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.


Huqingyutang (èƒ¡åº†ä½™å ‚) pharmacy




The outer wall of Huqingyutang (èƒ¡åº†ä½™å ‚): A renowned traditional Chinese medicine pharmacy. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.


 


The inside of Huqingyutang (èƒ¡åº†ä½™å ‚): It offers a diverse range of products including traditional Chinese medicines, health supplements, and herbal teas. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.





Huqingyutang (èƒ¡åº†ä½™å ‚) clinics, which specialize in providing traditional Chinese medicine services. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.


  





Hefang Street (æ²³åŠè¡—) offers an incredible variety of food, snacks and drinks. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.






æ™¯é˜³è§‚ (Jingyangguan)
æ™¯é˜³è§‚ (Jingyangguan): A renowned brand specializing in traditional Chinese pickled vegetables, commonly known as é…±èœ. Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.

 



ç¾Šæ±¤é¥­åº— (Yang Tang Restaurant)

ç¾Šæ±¤é¥­åº— (Yang Tang Restaurant), established in 1788 during the 53rd year of Emperor Qianlongâ€™s reign, is one of Hangzhouâ€™s oldest and most esteemed culinary establishments. When the Manchus arrived in Hangzhou, they avoided pork and instead opened a lamb-focused restaurant, which became known for its lamb-centric dishes. The restaurantâ€™s signature offerings include ç¾Šè‚‰çƒ§å– (Lamb Shaomai) and ç¾Šæ‚æ±¤ (Lamb Offal Soup). Photo captured by Weisi on 4 Jan 2025.

title: About me
text: Welcome to my personal website! I am a pharmacist and data analyst based in Sydney, Australia. I am currently a data analyst working at the university of New South Wales (UNSW).I am passionate about programming, data analysis, data visualization and statistical modelling.See my CV for more details.

title: About me
text:
Education
March 2023: The university of New South Wales (UNSW), M.S Health data science, WAM 88 (HD)  Dissertation: Changes in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk over time among people living with HIV
March 2019: The university of Sydney, B.S Pharmacy

title: About me
text:
Experience
July 2023 - Present: The university of New South Wales (UNSW), Sydney, NSW  Data scientist, School of population health
Feb 2023 - Dec 2023: The university of Sydney, Sydney, NSW  Data scientist/Research officer, School of pharmacy
March 2023 - Present: Sydney, NSW  Registered pharmacist

title: Weisi Chen
text:
Welcome to my personal website!
Born and raised in Hangzhou, China, I moved to Sydney, Australia in 2015 to pursue university studies. I am a highly disciplined and hard-working individual with a strong passion for programming, data analysis, data visualization, and statistical modeling. With a background in pharmacy and health data science, I am interested in population-level analysis using linked health data. My expertise lies in uncovering meaningful insights from complex datasets, driven by a commitment to improving health outcomes. I thrive on tackling challenging problems with analytical precision and creativity, always striving to deliver impactful results in every project I undertake.
I am currently a data scientist working at the university of New South Wales (UNSW) in Sydney, Australia. In my free time, I enjoy reading, photography, exploring cities on foot, traveling, learning/exploring new things and cherishing moments with family and friends.

title: About Nanjing | é‡‘é™µå°è±¡
text: A flock of doves soaring through the sky is a romance unique to Jinling City (the old name of Nanjing). Doves are free, and so are you.
